moves.1. e4: The gold standard of opening moves.
moves.1... d5: The Center Counter Defense, a very sharp line.
moves.2... Qxd5: The immediate recapture usually leads to immediate tactics.
moves.3... Qa5: The usual, and good, response. Now White cannot advance the QP without causing a self-pin.
moves.4. Bc4: Benschop develops aggressively. She is trying to exploit White's advantage in time this line generates.
moves.4... Nf6: Gruenenwald proceeds with her own development.
moves.5. d3: Submitting to the self-pin in order to protect one Bishop and open a line for the other.
moves.5... Bf5: Gruenenwald has neutralized the advantage in time with this move.
moves.6. Bd2: Breaking the pin and threatening a counter. White's Knight can now move with a discovery to Black's Queen.
moves.6... c6: Clearing a diagonal for the Queen's potential retreat.
moves.7. Qe2: Clearing the way to castle Q-side, with a pin on the Black KP.
moves.8. Nb5: Benschop exploits the discovery on the Queen, with a further threat of N-B7 ch winning the Exchange. Gruenenwald resigns.

players: Anne Marie Benschop (NED) vs. Evi Gruenenwald (SUI)
